content: WPP (WPPGY) shares are plunging after the world's largest advertising company cut its full-year revenue forecast amid lower spending by customers, in particular consumer-goods manufacturers.WPP said like-for-like revenue growth is expected to be 0% and 1% in 2017. That's down from an earlier 2% forecast.  The stock fell as much as 12 percent in London, the worst drop in 17 years. U.S. shares fell 11% to 91 in morning trade on the stock market today in New York.Advertising companies worldwide are being hit as big clients like Unilever (UN) and Procter & Gamble (PG) focus on cost-cutting to cope with sluggish global economic growth and technological disruption. London-based WPP singled out ad spending on consumer goods — items such as laundry detergent and toothpaste that make up about one-third of its revenue  — as coming under particular pressure.Consumer-goods giant Unilever, one of WPP's biggest customers, said earlier this year that it would cut ad output by 30% and halve the number of creative agencies it works with to 1,500 from 3,000. That followed a failed takeover bid by Kraft Heinz (KHC), which was the "seminal" moment in the first quarter, according to WPP Chief Executive Officer Martin Sorrell."That sent a shockwave through the industry," Sorrell said by phone. "It obviously had an effect in terms of people spending, particularly in the packaged goods sector."WPP, which also works for brands such as Ford (F) and Marks & Spencer, had already seen its shares fall 12% this year through Tuesday amid a difficult economic climate and pressure on its businesses in North America. It's now down more than 20% year-to-date in London. Its biggest rivals, including Interpublic Group (IPG), Publicis Groupe and Omnicom (OMC), are each down more than 8% this year.Publicis dropped 2.9% in Paris, while IPG and Omnicom were down more than 4% in U.S. trading. Shares of European television companies including TF1, ProSiebenSat.1 Mediaand ITVc declined as well.In March, WPP had its biggest drop since the financial crisis when WPP gave its initial forecast for 2% growth, the slowest pace since 2009.In the second quarter, WPP's like-for-like net sales fell 0.5% with July declining 2.6%, and North America and Western Continental Europe were the poorest performing regions."Some of the weakness was expected, however this is still an incremental disappointment," Tamsin Garrity, an analyst at Jefferies Group, said in a research note.WPP said that it didn't experience any significant loss in revenue from clients or of data from a cyberattack it suffered in June. The attack took down WPP's website and caused disruptions across businesses including the creative agency Ogilvy and Mather, a person familiar with the matter said at the time.The attack cost WPP about $10 million, $5 million of which was covered by insurance, Sorrell said. The company will spend about $10 million to $15 million annually on increased protection against future attacks, he said.

Led by consumer electronics giant Apple (AAPL), technology companies continue to have the most valuable brands in the world, though athletic gear maker Nike (NKE) and industrial giant General Electric (GE) also earned top spots.

Apple's brand is valued at $170.28 billion, up 43% from a year ago, Interbrand said. Technology companies accounted for six of the top 10 and a third of the $1.71 trillion value of all brands on the market tracker's latest top 100 list, released Sunday.
Apple was No. 1 for the third year in a row, followed by Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google, valued at $120.31 billion (up 12%), and Coca-Cola (KO) with $78.42 billion (down 4%).
Microsoft (MSFT) was No. 4 with $67.67 billion (up 11%), and IBM (IBM) was No. 5 with $65.1 billon (down 10%).
Apple shares closed up 0.4% in Monday trading on the stock market today. Alphabet rose 2.2%. Coca-Cola gained 1.5%, Microsoft 2.3% and IBM 3%.

Rounding out the top 10 were Toyota (TM) valued at $49.05 billion (up 16%), Samsung at $45.3 billion (unchanged), General Electric at $42.28 billion (down 7%), McDonald's (MCD) at $39.81 billion (down 6%), and Amazon.com (AMZN) at $37.95 billion (up 29%).
Among other notable names, entertainment and media conglomerate Disney (DIS) was No. 13 with $36.5 billion, and Nike was No. 17 with $23.1 billion.
Five brands that saw the steepest increases in value were Facebook (FB) (up 54%), Apple, Amazon, Paris-based luxury goods company Hermes (up 22%), and Nissan Motor (NSANY) which rose 22% to No. 41.

Whenever you see a television commercial for a global brand, there's a good chance one of the many companies under Omnicom Group's (OMC) umbrella is behind it.

The New York-based company, which owns global ad agencies BBDO Worldwide, DDB Worldwide and TBWA Worldwide, counts among its clients Apple (APPL), General Electric (GE), McDonald's (MCD), PepsiCo (PEP) and Visa (V). That's just a fraction of its worldwide brand customer base.

It also runs national ad agencies that serve companies including AT&T (T), Citigroup (C) and Southwest Airlines (LUV). That's not all. Omnicom also offers media buying, public relations and other communications services. Its 2013 merger deal with France's Publicis Groupe was called off in May 2014.
The U.S. accounted for just over half, 52%, of 2013 revenue, followed by European markets at 16%, the U.K. 9% and other 23%.

With the exception of a decline in 2009, partly during the recession, Omnicom has grown its annual profit by 7% or more during the past decade. Analysts expect growth to continue at 9% for 2014 and 8% this year.
Thanks to the steady track record, the ad agency scores a 1 for its three-year Earnings Stability Factor on a scale from 0 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile).
The ad giant currently pays a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share, or $2 for the full year. That works out to a yield of 2.7%, above the 1.95% average payout of the S&P 500.
The company increased its dividend the past five years, after keeping the payout steady during the 2007-09 recession.
A neutral C Accumulation/Distribution Rating is offset by an up-down volume ratio of 1.5, implying positive demand for shares.

Stock futures pointed to a weak start Monday as the market headed for the last trading day of August and the final week of the summer.
Dow futures traded 105 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 23.7 points and S&P 500 futures showed a 13.3-point loss. All were off early lows.

The stock market today launches with the Nasdaq down 5.9%, the S&P 500 off 5.5% so far in August, tracking toward the worst monthly performance for both indexes since May 2012. But it could have been much worse.
The Nasdaq opens 60% of the way up the month's trading range, after rebounding from a 16% dive. The S&P 500 opens just below the midpoint in its trading range for the month.
The market remains in a correction. Savvy investors can put the pause to good use by building watch lists of stocks with strong fundamentals forming possible bases.
A fairly light week of economic news gets the Federal Reserve's September Beige Book report due out Wednesday, and ramps up to the Labor Department's August payrolls report on Friday.
Today, Kingsbury International reports its Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for August at 9:45 a.m. ET. The Dallas Federal Reserve delivers its regional manufacturing survey at 10:30 a.m.
In stocks, the second quarter earnings season is mostly passed, with only a handful of big names - mostly retailers- expected this week.

New Jersey-based biotech Medicines Co. (MDCO) popped 20% ahead of the open. Early stage trial results presented in London on Sunday showed the shot-administered cholesterol treatment ALN-PCSsc - developed with partner Alnylam Pharmaceuticals (ALNY) - lowered LDL cholesterol levels by an average of 64% for more than 140 days. The results suggest a drug that could manage cholesterol levels through shots two or three times a year. Alnylam rose a fraction before the open.

Leading stocks were under some early pressure, with the bulk of the IBD 50 list steering mostly lower in premarket trade. Losses were mild, however. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Alaska Airlines (ALK) slipped furthest, falling less than 1%.

Overseas, China's markets posted a moderately mixed session with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index up 0.3% and the Shanghai Composite down 0.8%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dived 1.3%. Europe's markets were also mixed, with the leading indexes in Paris and Frankfurt down a half percent, and London's FTSE 100 up 0.9% near midday.

The dollar eased vs. the euro and the yen. Bonds edged higher. Oil prices slipped in the 2% range, with West Texas Intermediate trading above $4 a barrel and Brent crude near $49. China — on track to surpass the U.S. as the world's largest economy later this year — wields increasing influence on the global merger and acquisition scene.
China's commerce ministry on Wednesday approved, with conditions, a $2.6 billion merger between Germany's Merck KGa and Luxembourg-based AZ Electronics Materials.

The approvals require Merck, the world's largest maker of the liquid crystals, to report any licensing deals it makes in China. They also prevent Merck from pressuring Chinese customers to do business with both companies.

Approvals from China were at least part of the reason that Microsoft's (MSFT) $7.2 billion acquisition of Nokia's devices business missed its first-quarter deadline. Chinese regulators approved the deal at the beginning of April. It is still pending as it wends through regulatory obstacles in India.

In February, Chinese regulators withheld approval of the $35 billion wedding of U.S.-based advertising giant Omnicom Group (OMC) and French rival Publicis Groupe. The deal, originally targeting a December closing, had been approved by all jurisdictions except China, the Financial Times reported in February.

The lack of Chinese approval delayed the deal — which would reportedly create the world's largest grossing advertising and communications firm — an estimated nine months, to the third quarter. In the mean time, friction has amped up between the two companies, potentially putting the entire combination in jeopardy.

The context for such regulatory muscle flexing was clear Wednesday, when the most recent figures from the International Comparison Program put China's economy on track to surpass the U.S. later this year — well ahead of the 2019 timetable generally referred to by economists.
Last calculated in 2005, the ICP study, hosted by World Bank, is based on purchasing power parity — the buying strength of a currency in an economy.

The ICP put China's economy at 85% of the U.S. size in 2011, and growing at a much faster rate. The U.S. has been the world's largest economy since surpassing the United Kingdom in 1872, the report said.
China measured up at 43% vs. the U.S. in 2005. India's economy ranked third.

Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. The ad pricing traction that Facebook (FB) exhibited in the fourth quarter is continuing this quarter, says an analyst, who raised his price target on Facebook stock.

In a report released Monday, Eric Sheridan of UBS Securities says a few recent ad deals indicate a continued robust online ad market for Facebook. Sheridan raised his price target on Facebook stock to 90 from 72, while maintaining his buy rating.

Facebook stock was up nearly 2.5% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 71.50, and earlier touched an all-time high above 72. Facebook stock is No. 1 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing for the fifth consecutive week.

"Our Q1 advertiser channel checks suggest the pricing strength exhibited in Q4 (plus 92% year-over-year price per ad) has carried over into early 2014 and is likely sustainable for longer than our prior estimates had assumed," Sheridan wrote.

Reasons for the optimism include improved quality of advertisers and increased frequency of higher ad formats including mobile app ads and a report from Ogilvy & Mather that indicated a decline in organic page reach from 12% in October to 6% in February.

The decline "is acting as an impetus for greater ad spend as brand advertisers seek to maintain their audience — outsized ROIs on Facebook are more than sufficient to justify this greater spend," he wrote.
This month, Facebook launched a global partnership with snacks and candy manufacturer Mondelez International that covers 52 countries.
